skill.name: accessibility-compliance
skill.description: Implement WCAG 2.2 compliant interfaces with mobile accessibility, inclusive design patterns, and assistive technology support. Use when auditing accessibility, implementing ARIA patterns, building for screen readers, or ensuring inclusive user experiences.
skill.summary: Implement WCAG 2.2 compliant interfaces with mobile accessibility, inclusive design patterns, and assistive technology support.
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: This skill is a documentation-only reference for accessibility compliance. All 225 static findings are false positives caused by the scanner misinterpreting markdown code fences and documentation links as security issues. The 'Ruby/shell backtick execution' patterns are markdown code block delimiters (```tsx, ```typescript). The 'Hardcoded URL' patterns are legitimate links to accessibility standards resources (W3C, A11y Project). No executable code, network requests, or command execution is present. This skill is safe for publication.

content.value_statement: Build inclusive digital experiences that comply with WCAG 2.2 standards. This skill provides code patterns, guidelines, and best practices for screen readers, keyboard navigation, and mobile accessibility.
actual_capabilities: Generate WCAG 2.2 Level AA and AAA compliant code patterns
Implement accessible React components with proper ARIA attributes
Create keyboard-navigable interfaces with focus management
Build screen reader compatible content with semantic HTML and live regions
Design mobile-accessible interfaces for VoiceOver and TalkBack
Audit existing code for accessibility violations
limitations: Does not test or validate accessibility automatically
Does not replace manual testing with assistive technologies
Does not provide legal compliance certification
Does not include accessibility testing tool integration

use_cases.title: Building Accessible React Components
use_cases.description: Generate accessible button, modal, and form components with proper ARIA attributes, focus management, and keyboard support.
use_cases.target_user: Frontend developers building inclusive user interfaces

use_cases.title: Accessibility Code Review
use_cases.description: Review code for WCAG compliance issues including color contrast, semantic HTML, and accessibility attribute correctness.

use_cases.title: Mobile App Accessibility
use_cases.description: Implement touch target sizing, gesture alternatives, and assistive technology support for iOS and Android applications.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Component Accessibility
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an accessible [component name] component that follows WCAG 2.2 guidelines. Include proper ARIA attributes, keyboard navigation support, and screen reader announcements.
prompt_templates.scenario: Generating a single accessible UI component

prompt_templates.title: Form with Validation
prompt_templates.prompt: Build an accessible form with proper labeling, error handling, and live region announcements. Include error messages linked via aria-describedby and keyboard-accessible validation.
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating accessible form with accessibility validation

prompt_templates.title: Modal Dialog
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement an accessible modal dialog with focus trapping, Escape key closure, proper ARIA roles (dialog, alertdialog), and focus return to trigger element on close.
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating accessible modal or dialog component

prompt_templates.title: Accessibility Audit
prompt_templates.prompt: Review the following code for WCAG 2.2 compliance. Check for semantic HTML, ARIA attributes, keyboard accessibility, color contrast, and screen reader compatibility. List any violations with fix suggestions.

output_examples.input: Create an accessible button component with loading state

output: - Return focus on close to trigger element

output_examples.input: Create accessible form with error handling
output: - Link from error summary to field
- Live region for form submission status

best_practices: Use semantic HTML elements first before adding ARIA attributes - native elements provide built-in accessibility
Ensure all interactive elements are keyboard accessible with visible focus indicators
Test with real assistive technologies (NVDA, JAWS, VoiceOver, TalkBack) during development
anti_patterns: Using role='presentation' on tables that contain meaningful data relationships
Removing outline styles without providing alternative visible focus indicators
Using aria-label or aria-labelledby without providing visible text alternatives

faq.question: What WCAG levels does this skill support?
faq.answer: This skill covers WCAG 2.2 Level A, AA, and AAA success criteria with specific guidance for each level.

faq.question: Does this skill automatically test my code for accessibility?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides patterns and guidance. Manual testing with assistive technologies and automated tools like axe DevTools are still recommended.

faq.question: What is the minimum touch target size for mobile accessibility?
faq.answer: WCAG 2.2 requires a minimum target size of 24x24 CSS pixels (Level AA) with a recommended 44x44 CSS pixels (Level AAA).

faq.question: When should I use aria-live regions?
faq.answer: Use aria-live regions to announce dynamic content changes to screen readers, such as form validation errors, search results updates, or loading state changes.

faq.question: What is the difference between aria-disabled and disabled?
faq.answer: The disabled attribute prevents keyboard interaction and focus. aria-disabled only announces the state to assistive technology but does not prevent interaction.

faq.question: How do I make custom keyboard shortcuts accessible?
faq.answer: Provide visible documentation of shortcuts, allow customization, ensure they do not conflict with browser shortcuts, and announce them via aria-keyshortcuts.
